notes: Highly aromatic, used in perfumes and garlands.
Used in hair care, herbal tea, and worship of Goddess Kali.

Symbol of love. Petals used in Gulkand and rose water.
National flower of India. Sacred in Hinduism and Buddhism.
Follows the sun. Seeds are edible and produce oil.
Winter flower available in many colors.
Hardy shrub with toxic but beautiful flowers.
Blooms year-round. Used in traditional medicine.
Intensely fragrant white flower used in perfumes and garlands.
Bright orange flowers that bloom in spring. Associated with Holi.
State flower of Kerala (Kanikonna), blooms during Vishu.
Waxy, fragrant flowers found in temples.
Blooms at night, falls by morning. Sweet fragrance.
Orange/peach flowers, popular in South India for hair adornment.
Vivid blue flowers used for tea (blue tea) and worship.
Yellow/orange highly fragrant celestial flower.
Cluster of small red/pink star-shaped flowers.
Papery colorful bracts, found everywhere in warm climates.
Often confused with Lotus, leaves float on water surface.
Traditional garden flower, distinct shape.
Large foliage, bright flowers, hard black seeds.
Popular annual garden flower, many varieties.
Flowers change color from white to pink to red.
Sacred to Lord Shiva, but highly toxic.
Used for flavoring (kewra water) and perfumes.
Small star-shaped cream flowers, retain scent when dry.
Unique ball-like orange flowers. Associated with Lord Krishna.
Bright red flowers. Different from Night Jasmine (also called Parijat).
Common wild shrub with multi-colored flower clusters.
Leaves fold when touched. Pink fluffy flowers.
Climbing vine with trumpet-shaped flowers.
Popular garden flower with complex petals.
Tall flower spikes, popular in bouquets.
Sacred tree. Flowers are orange-yellow.
Milky latex. Favorite flower of Lord Ganesha.
Striking red/orange/yellow flowers.
Trumpet shaped yellow flowers. Toxic.
Rich in iron/fiber. Commonly cooked as a vegetable.
Bitter taste. Used in Ugadi Pachadi and rasam.
Edible flowers, cooked as fritters or curry.

Extremely fragrant at night.
